SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the respondent submitting this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will be easily answered by some whereas others may prove impossible for you to answer; you may have answers about leaving blank spaces. The questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1864, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Buy?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer education experience
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of our permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

Received Apr 27 1953
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A. A brief self-examination in relation to the question

B. Answering the questionnaires

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences. Some of the questions here will not apply to everyone, but others may prove impossible for you to answer; so try to reply to each question as best you can.

Try to be brief (not less than five words), or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of his pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write than on separate sheets or supply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Pioneer Past: That Old Western Canadian Pioneer Days" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

2. Your address: YELLOW GRASS SASK.

3. Date: April 18, 1953

5. What was your father's name and occupation? THOMAS MURRAY, Farmer and Stockman

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) October 1st, 1879

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

    By living here.

Worked on homestead until 18 years old.
